results.title: Spotlights: George Miller
results.brief_description: An Australian filmmaker and former physician. He is best known for his Mad Max franchise, whose second instalment, Mad Max 2 (1981), and fourth, Fury Road (2015), have been hailed as among the greatest action films of all time.

constellations_primary.name: George Miller
constellations_primary.description: For a guy who started his career as a physician, George Miller sure is a diverse filmmaker.

results.description: An Australian filmmaker and former physician, George Miller is best known for his Mad Max franchise, whose second instalment, Mad Max 2 (1981), and fourth, Fury Road (2015), have been hailed as among the greatest action films of all time. George discusses storytelling and how it helps us make our way through the world.
description_for_label: An Australian filmmaker and former physician, George Miller is best known for his Mad Max franchise, whose second instalment, Mad Max 2 (1981), and fourth, Fury Road (2015), have been hailed as among the greatest action films of all time. results.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
results.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.
description_for_label: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.

results.title: Mamadrama
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, Arte, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen and Amber Films
results.brief_description: An Australian documentary examining the portrayal of Jewish mothers on the big screen. From an early age filmmaker Monique Schwarz was puzzled by the discrepancy between the domineering and emasculating Jewish mothers typically represented on film, and her own mother, a Holocaust survivor. “Mamadrama” consequently has a strong personal touch, via the reflections of Schwarz and interviews with directors Paul Mazursky, Paul Bogart, and Larry Peerce, and actress Lainie Kazan. In addition to well-known Hollywood movies “Mamadrama” uses rare footage from early silent films, Yiddish language features and Israeli films. The tone of the documentary is reflective rather than critical; the most intriguing moments emerge from the candour with which the interviewees discuss their own mothers.

results.title: The Gulf between
results.brief_description: Fired from 1000 kilometers away, 39 scud missiles hit Israel during the Gulf War. Two people died as a result of direct hits. Twelve people died from related causes. Thousands of buildings were destroyed. For Israelis the impact of this war spread far beyond this… This documentary uncovers the personal feelings and stories of six ordinary Israelis as they reflect on their experiences during the Gulf War and their belief in the hatred towards Israel by the surrounding Arab States. It would appear that most Israelis want peace but do not agree on how to achieve this end - resigned to the fact that perhaps co-existence with the Palestinians is the only way. However, the Israelis have lived through many wars: War of Independence (1948); Suez crisis (1956); Six Day War (1967); Yom Kippur War (1973); Lebanon War (1982); and are determined not to back down from their fight to keep Israel as the rightful home for Jewish people. Contains strong images of the aftermath of the Gulf War, archival footage of the Holocaust and interviews.

results.title: Apollo 10: around the moon
results.creator_credit: United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration
results.brief_description: The film shows various footage of Apollo 10’s travel around the moon including: the Command module filmed from the Lunar module; the far side of the moon; Command module over landing site No. 2; view from Lunar module sixty miles up; inside the Lunar module; Lunar module descent and much more.

results.title: Strange creature: the echidna
results.brief_description: A simplified version for schools and general audiences of the prize-winning CSIRO film “The Echidna”. Experienced naturalists have seen for the first time in this film the young echidna in its mother’s pouch at different stages of growth. Highlights its uniqueness as an egg-laying mammal and shows the echidna in its natural habitat, feeding, reproductive techniques and development of the young.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film is shot in New Guinea and features the filmmaker’s family and friends, locals, people gathering in vast numbers for celebrations in various traditional dress, Chinese dragon display, scenic views, and road safety issues. Most likely filmed around Goroka, as the filmmaker lived mainly in Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden
00:03:23:00 car wreck being towed away and off the road
00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences
